# Project Style & VEX Conventions
_Last updated: 2025-08-25_

## Terminology (hard rule)
- Do **not** use the term **“actor”** to describe people or organisations anywhere in this project.
- Use **“party,” “person,”** or **“entity”** instead — and when naming, prefer the exact role/title: **“PC Dixon,” “Sgt Duffy,” “PC Gasson,” “Liz (front desk).”**

## VEX tag conventions
- Replace legacy `ACTOR::NAME` tags with **`PARTY::NAME`** (e.g., `PARTY::DIXON`, `PARTY::GASSON`).
- Each VEX entry should also include a **people** array of human-readable names.

**Example VEX entry (excerpt):**
```json
{
  "vex_id": "A06-L0123",
  "speaker": "Sussex Police 101 Call Handler",
  "quote": "It shows the first note on 24/07/2024 but it's under November.",
  "tags": ["PARTY::DIXON", "TIMELINE::FIRST_NOTE", "TIMELINE::MONTH_NOV"],
  "people": ["PC Dixon"],
  "contradictions": ["CONTRADICTION::JULY_FIRST_NOTE_DISPLAYS_AS_NOVEMBER"]
}
```

## Linting / CI guardrails
Run the linter before commits or wire it into CI. This fails on:
- Any `ACTOR::` tags
- Any standalone word `actor` / `actors` (case-insensitive)

```bash
bash ./lint_no_actor.sh
```

To make this a git **pre-commit** hook:
1. Copy `pre-commit.sample` to `.git/hooks/pre-commit`.
2. `chmod +x .git/hooks/pre-commit`
3. Commit as normal — the hook will block violations.

## Quick one-off cleanup (shell)
```bash
# Convert legacy tags (safe)
grep -RIl --exclude-dir=.git --include='*.json' 'ACTOR::' . | xargs -I{} sed -i -E 's/ACTOR::/PARTY::/g' {}

# Audit for stray wording (review before replacing)
grep -RIn --exclude-dir=.git -E '\bactor(s)?\b' .
```

sections.title: Complainant’s Foreword
sections.notes: Sets narrative frame, references Kim Box and purpose of documentation.

sections.notes: Allegations list + three interconnected timelines (Sussex Police, Brighton Fringe, Personal Evidence).

sections.title: Master Complaint (Full)
sections.notes: Primary narrative and evidence map; overrides earlier sections if discrepancies exist.

allegations: Catastrophic safeguarding breaches by Sussex Police
Retaliation and governance failures by Brighton Fringe Ltd.

t1_sussex_police_chronology.summary: Initial report, dismissal by PC Gore, and alleged deletion of recordings by PC Jon Dixon (7 Nov 2024).
Victim-blaming and procedural breaches including unredacted email forward (12 Feb 2025), no BWV on flat visit, and inversion on 22 Apr 2025.
Conflicting case start dates; 27 Apr 2025 NFA email to suspect prior to scheduled safeguarding meeting.
SAR obstruction; suicide attempt on 6 Apr 2025 not logged; 22 Apr misuse of GDPR; 25 Jun SAR refusal after closure.

t2_brighton_fringe_consequences.summary: Safeguarding disclosures sent to Brighton Fringe; no action taken.
Retaliation, defamation claims, contact with GP without consent, and narrative control/erasure of branding.

t3_personal_evidence_construction.summary: Lockdown of evidence after learning suicide attempt not logged; full preservation of calls/voicemails; SAR filed 8 Apr 2025 and refused 25 Jun 2025.

payload.title: The Retaliatory Hang-Up: Refusal of Service Upon Recognition
payload.summary: This section analyses two back-to-back 101 calls (04:56 and 05:00) that were terminated by Sussex Police the moment the victim began to speak. Occurring just minutes after the Humiliation Protocol call, these hang-ups represent a coordinated and retaliatory refusal of service against a whistleblower. These actions amount to a calculated breach of duty and obstruction of victim rights.
source_documents: 22-06-25_04:56_101_Call_“hung up just from seeing why was calling_en-GB.txt
22-06-25_05:00_101_Call_“just enjoying being erased now, pencilling myself back in”.txt

key_points.title: The Incidents
key_points.text: Both calls ended immediately upon connection with a live handler. The first ends with the victim saying, “Hung up just from seeing who was calling.” The second is even more damning: the victim attempts to report the previous hang-up and is hung up on again. The sound of the call dropping and the final 'Fucking hell' confirm retaliation.

key_points.title: The Context is Everything
key_points.text: These events occurred within minutes of the victim confronting Sussex Police over crime number manipulation and institutional cover-up. This timing strongly implies the calls were terminated deliberately as retaliation.

key_points.title: Constructive Refusal of Service
key_points.text: Sussex Police denied the victim their legal right to report incidents or access safeguarding by cutting the call based on recognition alone. This constitutes a serious breach of the Victims’ Code and fundamental duty of care.

key_points.title: Retaliation Against a Whistleblower
key_points.text: Rather than respond to the allegations, the police silenced the victim. These hang-ups are not glitches — they are punishments. They reflect institutional recognition and retaliatory targeting of someone holding the system accountable.

payload.conclusion: These recordings are brief but powerful. They expose Sussex Police's strategy of silencing through technical denial. This was not a mistake — it was a retaliation. These events must be treated as serious police misconduct and referred to the IOPC.
